properties.Title: Tropical Cyclone Information Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: For Post-tropical Storm Erin. This is a special meteorological summary for Post-tropical Erin. This is the final information statement for this storm. 1. Full discussion of the event: On Monday, August 26th, the circulation around an area of low pressure halfway between Bermuda and Carolina coast became better defined. At the time, the convection southeast of the centre was persistent and the initial wind speed was set at 55 km/h. The depression remained poorly organized during the day. Slight strengthening was expected during the Tuesday to Wednesday period due to diminishing deep layer wind shear, warm sea surface temperatures and an approaching baroclinic trough. On Tuesday the 27th, satellite imagery showed that despite the presence of several swirls rotating around a centre, the circulation had remained poorly defined. The cloud pattern continued to improve during the day, and by the end of it, the convection had developed near the centre of the circulation. Based on subjective satellite analysis the intensity estimate was increased to 65 km/h, or tropical storm intensity. However by the morning of Wednesday, August 28th, the system became less organized and the intensity estimate was lowered to 55 km/h. At that time, global models indicated that the interaction between an approaching trough and Erin or its remnants could deepen the system as a post-tropical low on Thursday. Satellite imagery showed the merging of post-tropical low Erin and an approaching baroclinic trough during the early morning of Thursday, August 29th. Post-tropical depression Erin reached the South shore of Nova Scotia Thursday evening, passing east of Shelburne with a central pressure near 1005 millibars. It then travelled northeastward past St Margarets Bay and Halifax in the early hours of Friday, August 30th. It was accompanied by southerly winds gusting between 50 to 75 km/h. The weakening system then reached the southern Gulf of St. Lawrence in the morning. It was established earlier in the week that the main impact to be expected from this transitioning storm was going to be rainfall. Rain bands reached the Maritimes during the day Thursday, and several rounds of heavy rain affected parts of southern New Brunswick, western and northern Nova Scotia and western Prince Edward Island. At the peak of the rainfall, several surface stations reported rainfall rates in excess of 30 millimetres per hour which gave increased surface runoff and flooding. As an example, the last round of rain brought 66 millimetres at Baccaro Point in less than two hours. 2. Summary of rainfall amounts in millimetres: Parrsboro: 162 Port Maitland: 155 Scots Bay: 152 Greenwood: 127 Nappan: 121 Kentville: 115 Baccaro Point: 99 Yarmouth: 79 Summerside: 67 Fredericton: 56 Mechanic Settlement: 54 Halifax Stanfield Airport: 53 New Ross: 53 Moncton: 50 Halifax Windsor Park: 48 3. Summary of peak winds in kilometres per hour: Beaver Island: 76 Lunenburg: 72 Halifax Stanfield Airport: 69 Osborne Head: 67 Forecaster: Couturier. ### Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-08-30T22:59:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-30T09:12:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3313504849.2019
Area: Kings County, Annapolis County, Digby County, Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County, Cumberland County - Minas Shore, Cumberland County North and Cobequid Pass, Colchester County - Cobequid Bay, Colchester County North, Hants County, Colchester County - Truro and south, Halifax Metro and Halifax County West, Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Pictou County, Guysborough County, Antigonish County, Richmond County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County, Fredericton and Southern York County, Oromocto and Sunbury County, Grand Lake and Queens County, Sussex - Kennebecasis Valley and Kings County, Saint John and County, St. Stephen and Northern Charlotte County, Grand Manan and Coastal Charlotte County, Kent County, Moncton and Southeast New Brunswick, Kouchibouguac National Park, Fundy National Park, Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog has developed at Coral Harbour as a large, slow-moving low pressure system drifts near Southampton Island today. The fog may lift somewhat at times but is generally expected to continue today and tonight. Northerly winds will dissipate the fog Saturday morning when the low finally moves off towards Hudson Strait. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-31T06:26:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-30T14:27:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3860417989.2019
Area: Coral Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Extensive fog can be expected at Cape Dorset today through much of the weekend as a large, slow-moving low pressure system gradually drifts towards the community. The fog may lift somewhat at times, especially when heavier bands of rain affect the community, but in general extended periods of zero to near zero visibility can be expected into the weekend. The fog may begin to dissipate Sunday afternoon depending on the location of the low pressure system. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-31T11:25:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-30T19:26:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0505522566.2019
Area: Cape Dorset
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Extensive fog can be expected at Hall Beach and Igloolik today through Saturday as a large, slow-moving low pressure system gradually drifts towards the area. The fog may lift somewhat at times, especially when heavier bands of rain affect the community, but in general extended periods of zero to near zero visibility can be expected through to Saturday. The fog will begin to dissipate Saturday late afternoon depending on the location of the low pressure system. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-31T11:24:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-30T19:25:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3537965784.2019
Area: Hall Beach, Igloolik
properties.Author: Environment Canada
